channel.title: NYT > Sports > Tennis
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: For Venus and Serena Williams at the U.S. Open, Day and Night Experiences
item.description: Unlike her sister, Venus was not prepared to deal with questions about her tennis future after a loss in the first round of the singles tournament. “I’m just focused on the doubles,” she said.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Clarey
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Venus Williams lost in the first round to Alison Van Uytvanck of Belgium in straight sets.

item.title: With Upset Over Taylor Fritz, Brandon Holt Is Making a Name for Himself
item.description: Holt, a qualifier who inherited tennis skills from his mother, the U.S. Open winner Tracy Austin, and his other pastime — music — from his father, is putting together a tidy run at the tournament.
item.dc:creator: David Waldstein
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brandon Holt is the first wild-card qualifier to beat a top-10 seed.

item.title: Defending U.S. Open Champion Emma Raducanu Loses in the First Round
item.description: Raducanu, who won the U.S. Open women’s singles title as a qualifier without dropping a set last year, fell to Alizé Cornet in straight sets.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:credit: Julian Finney/Getty Images
item.media:description: Emma Raducanu failed to advance to the third round at any of the four Grand Slam tournaments this year.

item.title: Naomi Osaka, Serena Williams and One Last Shared U.S. Open
item.description: Osaka lost in the first round Tuesday to Danielle Collins, but would remember the final Grand Slam of the year for the front-row seat she had to her idol’s farewell party.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Naomi Osaka lost her first-round match to Danielle Collins in straight sets.

item.title: Serena Williams’s Next Opponent Is a Struggling Anett Kontaveit
item.description: They will face off in a packed Arthur Ashe Stadium on Wednesday, a venue that feels like home to Williams even if it has not always been a haven.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Clarey
item.media:credit: Jerry Lai/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
item.media:description: Anett Kontaveit will face Serena Williams for the first time in the second round at the U.S. Open.

item.title: Serena Williams Rises to the Occasion, Like So Many Times Before
item.description: Williams met a valedictory night at the U.S. Open with a win that was fitting, and with a second-round match on Wednesday, the farewell party at Arthur Ashe Stadium continues.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Clarey
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Serena Williams celebrating her win over Danka Kovinic on Monday night.

item.title: Serena Williams Fans Flock to the First Match of Her Final US Open
item.description: A star-studded crowd inside Arthur Ashe Stadium was joined by throngs of fans outside during Williams’s first-round U.S. Open match.
item.dc:creator: David Waldstein
item.media:credit: Sarah Stier/Getty Images
item.media:description: Fans cheered for Serena Williams of the United States after she won a point against Danka Kovinic of Montenegro. The night session Monday set an attendance record.

item.title: Serena Williams Wins First-Round Match Over Danka Kovinic at US Open
item.description: Williams will face the tournament’s No. 2 seed, Anett Kontaveit of Estonia, on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Serena Williams won, 6-3, 6-3, over Danka Kovinic of Montenegro.

item.title: Serena Williams’s No. 1 Supporter Is Her Daughter, Olympia
item.description: Olympia watched her mother in the first round of the U.S. Open from the stands of Arthur Ashe Stadium.
item.dc:creator: Lola Fadulu
item.media:credit: Kena Betancur/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Alexis Olympia Ohanian Jr., 4, took photos of her mother competing.

item.title: See the Celebrities and Politicians Who Were at Serena Williams’s Match
item.description: As well as Martina Navratilova, Mike Tyson, Katie Couric, Matt Damon, Spike Lee, Lindsey Vonn and Dr. Ruth Westheimer.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:credit: Mike Segar/Reuters
item.media:description: Anna Wintour, top center, the editor of Vogue, and Oracene Price, at center, Serena Williams’s mother, were among the guests in Williams’s player’s box.

item.title: In First Round of the US Open, a Ukrainian Player Upset Simona Halep
item.description: Daria Snigur, a 20-year-old ranked 124th in the world, burst into tears after beating Halep, a two-time major singles champion.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:credit: Danielle Parhizkaran/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
item.media:description: Daria Snigur of Ukraine upset Simona Halep in the first round of the U.S. Open.

item.title: On the First Day of US Open, All Eyes Are on Serena Williams
item.description: There are 63 other matches on opening day, but they have been relegated to the background as Williams prepares to play what could be her final singles match.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Clarey
item.media:credit: Matthew Stockman/Getty Images
item.media:description: Serena Williams has said this year’s U.S. Open is most likely her last.

item.title: Is Serena Williams the GOAT? Probably. Maybe. Without a Doubt.
item.description: Proclaiming the 23-time Grand Slam singles champion the greatest women’s tennis player of all time is a worthwhile debate, but not a straightforward one. First, define greatness.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Clarey

item.title: What Serena Williams Means to Her Fans
item.description: “She did things on her own terms and propelled herself to greatness, doing so in a sport that felt by design that it was off limits to Black people.”
item.dc:creator: Kurt Streeter and Elena Bergeron

item.title: In Comebacks, Serena Williams Showed ‘You Can Never Underestimate Her’
item.description: Big moments on the biggest stages cemented Williams’s reputation as the queen of comebacks.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Serena Williams during her comeback win at the 2012 US Open.

item.title: Serena Williams: 23 Grand Slam Titles, in the Books
item.description: The New York Times’s coverage of Williams’s 23 Grand Slam singles titles reflects more than two decades of greatness, and some surprises along the way.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Clarey
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Serena Williams’s Legacy On the Court All About Power and Intimidation
item.description: Serena Williams’s legacy is evident in the aggressive, all-action style of play that has become the norm on the women’s tennis tour.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Clarey
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Serena Williams Always Made a Strong First Impression
item.description: Long before Williams won 23 Grand Slam singles titles, she was turning heads. Countless memories fade, but not, it seems, when Williams was involved.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman
item.media:credit: Online USA via Getty Images
item.media:description: Richard Williams, left, practicing with Serena Williams in 1991 in Compton, Calif.

item.title: At the US Open, Data Analysts Are Just as Busy as the Players
item.description: A new era of data analysis has given players deeper insights into their opponents’ games and a strategic advantage.
item.dc:creator: Shira Springer
item.media:credit: Loren Elliott/Reuters
item.media:description: Every move of Novak Djokovic was captured during his quarterfinal match at the 2021 Australian Open.

item.title: Serena and Venus Williams, Before They Were Champions
item.description: A wowed Arthur Ashe invited a reporter to watch the Williams sisters. “Wait until you see them play,” he said. They were 10 and 11.
item.dc:creator: Cindy Shmerler
item.media:credit: Paul Harris/Online USA, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Serena, left, and Venus Williams in 1991. The two sisters have combined to win 30 major titles, 23 by Serena.

item.title: When One Tennis Major Title Is All There Is
item.description: After that first title, players are pestered with the question, when’s No. 2? Often, there is no next time.
item.dc:creator: Cindy Shmerler
item.media:credit: Ben Solomon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emma Raducanu won last year’s women’s U.S. Open for her first major title.

item.title: Serena Williams at the US Open: How to Watch Her First Match
item.description: The 23-time Grand Slam champion has a tough challenge in her second-round singles match on Wednesday at 7 p.m. at Arthur Ashe Stadium. She will also play doubles with her sister Venus on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Serena Williams during the first round of the U.S. Open on Monday night.

item.title: Chris Evert Needs Everyone to Listen
item.description: Since January, the 18-time Grand Slam champion has balanced her work in tennis with the grueling routine of chemotherapy for ovarian cancer. She never would have caught it early, if she hadn’t lost her sister to the same disease.
item.dc:creator: David Waldstein
item.media:credit: Melanie Metz for The New York Times

item.title: Brandon Holt, Tracy Austin’s Son, Wins a Spot in U.S. Open Main Draw
item.description: “She still warms me up,” Holt said of his mother, who won the U.S. Open twice. “She won’t miss one ball I hit back. Literally, not one. And if she does, she gets so mad.”
item.dc:creator: David Waldstein
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brandon Holt was granted a wild card into the qualifying tournament of the U.S. Open, where he won all three matches in the maximum three sets.

item.title: Can Coco Gauff the Tennis Prodigy Become a Tennis Legend?
item.description: Since Coco Gauff went pro at 14, she has played under the weight of high expectations. Now 18, she has her own measures for greatness.
item.dc:creator: Susan Dominus
item.media:credit: Arielle Bobb-Willis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Coco Gauff photographed at the Delray Beach Tennis Center.

item.title: Top Official Returns to the U.S. Open After Misconduct Suspension
item.description: Soeren Friemel served a one-year suspension and lost a top officiating job for inappropriate communication with an underling. The decision to bring him back has rankled some colleagues.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman
item.media:credit: Walter Luger/Sipa, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Earlier this year, Soeren Friemel resigned as the head of officiating with the International Tennis Federation.

item.title: At the U.S. Open, 5 Artists Get a Place in the Sun
item.description: Five sculptures, created by artists from underrepresented communities, will find a place in the sun at the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center in Queens until Sept. 11.
item.dc:creator: Kalia Richardson
item.category: Billie Jean King National Tennis Center
item.media:credit: Simbarashe Cha for The New York Times

item.title: Serena Williams Will Play Danka Kovinic at U.S. Open on Monday
item.description: Williams, who has said the Open is most likely her final tournament, will play 80th-ranked Danka Kovinic in the first round on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Clarey
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: Serena Williams practicing Thursday. She is a six-time U.S. Open singles champion.

item.title: Still Unvaccinated, Djokovic Says He Will Miss the U.S. Open
item.description: Djokovic said he wouldn’t be able to travel to New York for the tournament that begins next week. The U.S. has travel restrictions that require foreign visitors to be vaccinated against Covid-19.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman
item.media:credit: John Minchillo/Associated Press
item.media:description: Novak Djokovic had previously said that playing in the U.S. Open would be unlikely without a relaxing of travel rules for foreign visitors to the United States.

item.title: Victoria Azarenka Dropped From Ukraine Aid Event Before U.S. Open
item.description: The move came after players from Ukraine complained about the participation of Azarenka, a Belarusian, in the Tennis Plays for Peace Exhibition set for Wednesday night.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman
item.media:credit: Carolyn Kaster/Associated Press
item.media:description: Victoria Azarenka’s planned participation in the event to aid Ukraine was seen as a significant statement.
